title: Leicester helicopter tragedy inspiring Foxes in quest for Champions League qualification
text:

Gerry Taggart drove away from the King Power Stadium a year ago with his two sons relieved at Leicester's late fightback.

An 89th minute Wilfred Ndidi equaliser had earned the Foxes a belated point against 10-man West Ham .

Yet the scoreline and game soon became irrelevant as the club and entire city of Leicester were plunged into mourning by the devastating helicopter crash which claimed the lives of all five passengers, including the Foxes' wealthy Thai owner Vichai Srivaddhanaprabha.

It left former City defender Taggart reflecting on his own escape after being in the vicinity of the crash minutes before it happened.

The subsequent horrific fireball was like something from a disaster movie film set , not a Premier League football stadium.

(Image: Getty Images)

(Image: Getty Images)

But from the ashes of the appalling events has sprung a foundation in Leicester's late owner's name to generate funds for good causes.

And Taggart, who played for the club from 1998-2004, insists the 2016 champions are set for even greater future success as they look to honour the memory of tragic Vichai.

Taggart, 48, told Mirror Sport: “I met him on a couple occasions - he was always smiling.

“The first I knew of what happened was on my way. I was getting a lot of phone calls from some of the staff here.

“Both of my sons had been to the game with me. When I dropped them off I answered my phone and it was one of the girls from the club making sure I was OK.

“I said: why? And they told me what had happened.

(Image: SWNS.com)

(Image: PA)

“I then realised I had missed it by about two minutes because we had actually seen the fire brigade.

“I had my two kids in the car with me so it brought it home - 'wow', it could have been a lot worse for us.

“If I had left two minutes later I could have witnessed it or even worse for my family and many other people too.

“There was a lot of public grief afterwards and not just from the football club and the fans.

“The owners did a lot for the city of Leicester - especially for the children at the Leicester Royal Infirmary.

(Image: Sunday Mirror)

“That was one of the reasons why the outpouring was as great as it has been.

“It has taken a lot of time to get over what happened but now the ball is rolling.

“I expect in years to come the club will make sure they progress through the Vichai Foundation and ensure the legacy will stand the test of time.

“It is a massively important role for the club to play and the legacy of the owner and this football club will carry long into the future.

“That is one of their ambitions. I don't think they are anywhere near finishing it. We are just at the beginning of something.”

(Image: AFP via Getty Images)

(Image: PA)

In the days following Vichai's death , the King Power was turned into a huge shrine amid thousands of floral tributes.

More are expected on Saturday with fans planning 'A Walk for Vichai' from the City's Magazine Square to the stadium ahead of the Burnley home game.

On the exact anniversary a week on Sunday, Leicester will open a memorial garden at the crash site where staff members Kaveporn Punpare and Nusara Suknamai, and pilots Eric Swaffer and Izabela Lechowicz also died in the south-east corner.

The memorial will ensure the victims are never forgotten after Vichai's son Top succeeded his dad at the helm of the club and their duty free empire.

(Image: EMPICS Sport)

(Image: AFP/Getty Images)



Other bigger projects are in the pipeline too , including a state-of-the-art £100million new training ground to be opened next summer to mark 10 years since the club's Thai takeover.

Don't bet against it being named after the club's former chairman.

While there are also plans to expand the ground from its current 32,000 capacity.

But more than anything, Vichai came to symbolise a determined attitude to strive for excellence which paved the way for the club's amazing 5,000-1 title success.

It is this outlook that the close-knit club and its squad continue to aspire to in what is shaping up to be a highly-promising season under manager Brendan Rodgers.

(Image: Action Images via Reuters)

Rodgers, who succeeded Claude Puel in February, said: “The year has gone so fast but it comes upon us and the club will show the solidarity on and off the pitch that was really created by Vichai.

“The feeling he gave people, the players and staff, you cannot buy that.

“He was close to many people at the club and the players had a real affinity with him and still do.

“What I've tried to ensure since I've come in is to try to bring all that emotion out in a really positive way.

“Because he was a fighter and he wanted his teams to fight and he wanted his people to fight for the very best.

"I think that's what we see in the performances of the players and what we've tried to do since I came in.”
description: EXCLUSIVE: Leicester's players and fans will remember late owner Vichai Srivaddhanaprabha against Burnley this weekend
